q: Which is commonly an ancillary benefit?
explain: Ancillary commonly includes dental, vision, life, and disability.
why: Positioning voluntary benefits correctly expands choice without driving employer cost, improving retention.

q: Which dental plan design most encourages preventive care utilization?
explain: Covering preventive at 100% with tiered basic/major benefits nudges early care.
why: Preventive incentives lower downstream major claims and keep employees productive.

q: Short-term disability policies usually coordinate with which factor to avoid over-replacement of income?
choices: State disability programs and employer-paid leave
explain: STD often integrates with state DI and employer leave to keep replacement within policy limits.
why: Coordinating benefits avoids overpayment disputes and stabilizes pricing.

q: What is a dental waiting period?
choices: A time before specified services are covered
explain: Waiting periods defer coverage for certain services like major work.
why: Waiting periods can make new enrollees delay major services; setting expectations prevents dissatisfaction.

q: What is a dental annual maximum?
choices: Yearly cap on plan-paid dental benefits
explain: Annual maximums limit how much the plan pays each year.
why: Annual maximums cap plan liability; matching the cap to workforce needs balances premium and protection.

q: A vision allowance is…
choices: A fixed dollar amount toward frames or lenses
explain: Allowances pay toward frames/lenses up to a set amount.
why: Clear allowances avoid surprise costs and help employees use in-network vendors effectively.

q: What does AD&D add to a basic life policy?
choices: Additional benefit for accidental death or dismemberment
explain: AD&D pays an additional benefit for accidental death or qualifying dismemberment.
why: Knowing when AD&D applies prevents overestimating life coverage and supports accurate total comp messaging.

q: In LTD, what does the elimination period represent?
choices: Time between disability and benefit start
explain: The elimination period delays the first LTD payment by a specified number of days.
why: The elimination period determines cash-flow timing during disability—critical for employees living paycheck to paycheck.

q: LTD benefits being taxable or tax-free primarily depends on which factor?
choices: Whether the premium was paid pre-tax or post-tax
explain: If premiums are paid post-tax, benefits are generally tax-free; pre-tax premiums usually make benefits taxable.
why: Pre-tax vs. post-tax premium treatment flips whether LTD benefits are taxable—impacting take-home replacement.

q: Voluntary (employee-paid) benefits primarily…
choices: Expand choice without increasing employer premium spend
Are free to the employer and employee
explain: Voluntary programs add options while controlling employer cost.
why: Positioning voluntary benefits correctly expands choice without driving employer cost, improving retention.

q: A critical illness policy generally pays…
choices: A lump-sum upon diagnosis of a covered condition
explain: Pays a lump sum that can be used for any expense.
why: Lump-sum benefits can close financial gaps that medical plans don’t cover, reducing hardship after diagnosis.

q: Hospital indemnity insurance provides…
choices: Fixed cash per hospital event according to a schedule
explain: Pays fixed amounts per event, helping with deductibles and incidentals.
why: Fixed cash per event helps offset deductibles and lost wages, improving perceived value of the medical plan.

q: An Employee Assistance Program (EAP) offers…
explain: EAPs provide short-term counseling and resources to support well-being.
why: Early access to counseling and legal/financial support reduces absenteeism and supports a healthier culture.

q: What is a dental waiting period?
choices: A time before specified services are covered
explain: Waiting periods defer coverage for certain services like major work.
why: Waiting periods can make new enrollees delay major services; setting expectations prevents dissatisfaction.

choices: Yearly cap on plan-paid dental benefits
explain: Annual maximums limit how much the plan pays each year.
why: Annual maximums cap plan liability; matching the cap to workforce needs balances premium and protection.
